data.title: Code Helper using almost 100% CPU

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.14.2
- OS Version: macOS Sierra 10.12.6

I touched my mac and I felt it's hot, checked "Activity Monitor" and I saw "Code Helper" was using a lot of CPU (almost 100%). I was using only 1 window. I even killed process and closed VSC, but it was the same. I can close it, kill process and when I open VSC "Code Helper" again will take almost 100% CPU. After start it reaches about 180% CPU and it drops to ~100%.

As I tested, if you open VSC and you don't focus on it everything is OK. But if you open it and you press mouse click on VSC "Code Helper" goes crazy.

I can cook eggs on my mac ðŸ˜„ 

Extensions:

- PeterJausovec.vscode-docker
- arcticicestudio.nord-visual-studio-code
- dbaeumer.vscode-eslint
- esbenp.prettier-vscode
- formulahendry.auto-close-tag
- formulahendry.auto-rename-tag
- formulahendry.code-runner
- joelday.docthis
- msjsdiag.debugger-for-chrome
- robertohuertasm.vscode-icons
- xabikos.JavaScriptSnippets
- ziyasal.vscode-open-in-github

**I tried with and without extensions and it was the same!**

[7d48_main.cpuprofile.txt](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/files/1170206/7d48_main.cpuprofile.txt)
[7d48_renderer.cpuprofile.txt](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/files/1170207/7d48_renderer.cpuprofile.txt)

data.title: Test: loaded scripts explorer
data.body:
Test for #28521 and #31002:

Complexity: 3

- [x] Windows - **@egamma**
- [x] macOS- **@isidorn**
- [x] Linux - **@joaomoreno**

Previously loaded scripts could only be accessed via the "Open Loaded Script" action which uses a QuickPick UI.
With the new "Loaded Scripts" explorer it is possible to view and select loaded scripts in an explorer section in the debug viewlet.

Verify for both "legacy" and "inspector" protocols:
- the "Loaded Scripts" explorer is only visible if a node debug session is active
- the explorer shows new scripts as they are loaded
- scripts show up under the correct top level nodes:
  - first come the workspace root folders,
  - then scripts outside of the workspace
    - scripts under the user's home directory are abbreviated to '~' in linux and macOS 
  - then internal node scripts
- scripts show up under the correct top level nodes for (legacy) single folder workspaces and in non-folder mode 
- scripts in the explorer have the same path as the scripts shown in the QuickPick UI
- if more than one debug session is active, the explorer shows session nodes (which will not disappear if the number of debug sessions drops below two).
- selecting a leaf opens the script in a read only editor

Steps to Reproduce:

When I issue certain commands in the terminal, color code interpretation seems to break at certain points in the output:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1658949/28528361-c697ca54-708d-11e7-94f9-1ce864784729.png)

I don't know what it is specifically about the output that breaks the interpreter, but I can reproduce this at will with the CLI application I am using there.

To my knowledge, this worked previously and this works fine in other terminals.

data.title: Test snippet choice
data.body:
Test for: #17545
Complexity: 2

- [x] macOS- @isidorn
- [x] linux - @joaomoreno 


We have added support for snippet choice. That allows you to have a placeholder which a selection of value. When reaching that placeholder, one of the options is presented, e.g. in the following snippets the first placeholder is a selection, the 2nd isn't `${1|foo,bar,far,boo|} snippet ${2:fun}$0`. *Note* that current choice is handled as nested snippet and there a choice can only made once. Test that

* choice works as expected
* choice placeholders can be repeated and the choice is reflected in all locations
* choice parsing works with non trivial samples
* parsing never swallows things, e.g, `${1|not,choise}` is insert as is (note the missing pipe)
* you can escape the comma and pipe inside the choice with backslash. 
* this explains the basics well enough: https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/master/src/vs/editor/contrib/snippet/browser/snippet.md#L12

data.title: Git Extension: Expose APIs for external extensions
data.body:
This change allows to implement external extensions which could execute build in CI for list of modified files. It exposes following APIs:
* Get list of staged resources
* `git commit` command execution with a custom message
* `git push` command execution

More details and use case in #25838.

data.title: [php] Incorrect color for switch default label when using alt-syntax
data.body:
The keyword `default` is white like a regular label instead of purple if it is on a new line, has leading whitespace, and is followed by a colon.

```php
switch ($a):
  default:
    break;
endswitch;
```

data.title: Passing extra arguments with executeCommand
Block comment introduces spaces
data.body:
Adding a block comment adds spacing around the selection. Removing the comment leaves the space?

I'm sure this wasn't happening before 1.14...

I looked in the issues and in the documentation, apparently there is no Linux/UNIX manpage for the `code` command which is installed on *NIX systems when install VSCode.
Could it be added? It could be minimalist, generated automatically (e.g., with `pandoc`) from the `code --help` message.

data.title: CLI: parameter for opening a file at a buffer index (instead of line:column)

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
Hi,
I am not sure if this is useful or the right way, but maybe others find this userful as well.

I have write a simple Docstring system for powershell function, and for my `Regex` matches I unly get the buffer index of the match.

I don't know a simple way to get the line and column from this, which i need to use the `file:line[:character]` syntax decribed in [Commandline help ](https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/editor/command-line).

A possibility to open a file at a certain buffer position would be helpful for me. I have not thought about any specific  syntax for that.

---|---|---
cpptools|ms-|0.12.1
csharp|ms-|1.11.0



---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create project with c_cpp_properties.json include path that has "${INCLUDE}" where INCLUDE is an environment variable
2. Create tasks file where the command is "${env:MSBUILD}" where MSBUILD is an environment variable

Expected: Syntax is the same for both environment variable expansions.
Actual: c_cpp_properties.json and tasks use different syntaxes.  One of them requires the "env:" prefix and the other one doesn't.

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes/No

data.title: 2 panes have different line lengths even when splitter is centered

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.14.2 (cb82febafda0c8c199b9201ad274e25d9a76874e, 2017-07-19T23:34:09.706Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.15063
- Extensions: 

Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---
spellright|ban|1.0.27
python|don|0.6.9
cpptools|ms-|0.12.1
csharp|ms-|1.11.0
PowerShell|ms-|1.4.1
sort-lines|Tyr|1.3.0
---

If I have the same file open in a 2-pane view, with the vertical splitter exactly centered (I've even double-clicked it to confirm it's in the center), then the editor in each pane has a different maximum line length. Please see the attached screenshot for an example. Here, I've enabled word wrapping, and I've got the same file open in both editors. Notice that on the left side I've got the letter 'B' as the last character on the first line and then the letter 'C' wraps to the next line. But on the right side the letters 'B' and 'C' both wrap to the next line. In this example, the editor on the left can fit 71 characters, while the editor on the right can only fit 70 characters.
![vscode_line_lengths](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3789849/28514868-8268b3f0-7053-11e7-943f-efba9a5a6cfb.png)



<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes/No

data.title: Creating multiple sub folders at once
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.15.0 insider
- OS Version: Win Srv 2012 64 bit

## Steps to Reproduce:

In Java, and probably other languages, it is common to have deep directory structures. In those cases a directory structure can often look like this:
- src/main/java/com/domain/projectname

Results in the following folder tree:
```
\src
\src\main
\src\main\java
\src\main\java\com
\src\main\java\com\domain
\src\main\java\com\domain\projectname
```

In IDE's like `Intellij` or `Eclipse` folders like these are easily created by just typing the whole string with slashes `/` or backslashes `\`. This doesn't seem to be possible in `VS Code`.

1. Select `New Folder`
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/10828570/28513819-e7e38e68-7057-11e7-8ffa-334b612813be.png)
2. Type the string `src/main/java/com/domain/projectname`
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/10828570/28513850-03f69186-7058-11e7-82d7-d846a4adb832.png)

I believe this is a feature request.

data.title: Smoke test: Search viewlet results string change, wrong replacement
data.body:
Please see TFS build id 30850. 

You need to update smoke test to match against new search results string. Although I would say that we should preserve the string as it was in a single-root case, why would we display string with 'in 1 folder' if there is only single folder opened?

There also seems to be an issue with search result replacement that gives wrong number of changes after replacement happens.

data.title: Terminals launched with invalid paths hang during creation and never emit onExit
data.body:

- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.15063
- Extensions: 

Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---
cpptools|ms-|0.12.1
csharp|ms-|1.11.0

---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open an empty folder with VSCode
2. Configure a new MSBuild task
3. Try building (execute task)

Expected: Fails gracefully somehow
Actual: Just spins forever and never dies until I manually kill the task.

Note: this also happens when I mistype a path or something in the command to a directory that say for example doesn't exist.  If the command is wrong in some way, the task will just spin forever.

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes/No
